turns.speaker: CRAWFORD
turns.text: Starling, Clarice M., good morning.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: Good morning, Mr. Crawford.

turns.speaker: CRAWFORD
turns.text: Your instructors tell me you're doing well. Top quarter of the class.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: I hope so. They haven't posted anything.

turns.speaker: CRAWFORD
turns.text: A job's come up and I thought about you. Not really a job, more of - an interesting errand. Walk me to my car, Starling.

turns.speaker: CRAWFORD
turns.text: We're trying to interview all of the serial killers now in custody, for a psychobehavioral profile. Could be a big help in unsolved cases. Most of them have been happy to talk to us. They have a compulsion to boast, these people... Do you spook easily, Starling?

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: Not yet.

turns.speaker: CRAWFORD
turns.text: You see, the one we want most refuses to cooperate. I want you to go after him again today, in the asylum.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: Who's the subject?

turns.speaker: CRAWFORD
turns.text: The psychiatrist - Dr. Hannibal Lecter.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: Yes, well... Okay, right. I'm glad for the chance, sir, but - why me?

turns.speaker: CRAWFORD
turns.text: You're qualified and available. And frankly, I can't spare a real agent right now.

turns.speaker: CRAWFORD
turns.text: Now. I want your full attention, Starling. Are you listening to me?

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: Yes sir.

turns.speaker: CRAWFORD
turns.text: Be very careful with Hannibal Lecter. Dr. Chilton at the asylum will go over the physical procedures used with him. Do not deviate from them, for any reason. You tell him nothing personal, Starling. Believe me, you don't want Hannibal Lecter inside your head... Just do your job, but never forget what he is.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: And what is that, sir?

turns.speaker: CRAWFORD
turns.text: I've read your interim memo on Lecter. You sure you've left nothing out?

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: It's all there, sir, practically verbatim.

turns.speaker: CRAWFORD
turns.text: Every word, Starling? Every gesture?

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: Right down to the kleenex I used.  Sir, why? Is something wrong?

turns.speaker: CRAWFORD
turns.text: He mentioned a name, at the very end. "Mofet..." Any followup on her?

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: I spent all evening on the mainframe. Lecter altered or destroyed most of his patient histories, prior to capture. No record of anyone named Mofet. But "Split City" sounded like it might have have something to do with divorce. I tracked it down in the library's catalogue of national yellow pages.  It's a mini-storage facility outside Baltimore, where Lecter had his practice.

turns.speaker: CRAWFORD
turns.text: Well? Why aren't you there right now?

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: Sir, that's a field job. It's outside the scope of my assignment. And I've got a test tomorrow on -

turns.speaker: CRAWFORD
turns.text: Do you recall my instructions to you, Starling? What were they?

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: To complete and file my report by 0800 Wednesday. But sir -

turns.speaker: CRAWFORD
turns.text: Then do that, Starling. Do just exactly that.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: Sir, what is it? There's something you're not telling me.

turns.speaker: CRAWFORD
turns.text: Miggs has been murdered.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: Murdered...? How?

turns.speaker: CRAWFORD
turns.text: The orderly heard Lecter whispering to him, all afternoon, and Miggs crying. They found him at bed check. He'd swallowed his own tongue... Chilton is scared stiff the family will file a civil rights lawsuit, and he's trying to blame it on you. I told the little prick your conduct was flawless.  Starling...?

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: I'm here, sir, I just - I don't know how to feel about it.

turns.speaker: CRAWFORD
turns.text: You don't have to feel any way about it. Lecter did it to amuse himself. Why not, what can they do? Take away his books for awhile, and no jello...  I know it got ugly today. But this is your report, Starling - take it as far as you can. On your own time, outside of class. Now carry on.

turns.speaker: CRAWFORD
turns.text: Blue square for Belvedere, Ohio, where the Bimmel girl was abducted. Blue triangle where her body was found - down here in Missouri. Same marks for the other four girls, in different colors. This new one, today... washed up here.  Elk River, in West Virginia, about six miles below U.S. 79. Real boonies.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: There's no correlation at all between where they're kidnapped and where they're found...?  What if - what if you trace the heaviest-traffic routes backwards from the dump sites? Do they converge at all?

turns.speaker: CRAWFORD
turns.text: Good idea, but he thought of it, too. We've run simulations, using different vectors and the best dates we can assign. You put it all in the computer, and smoke comes out. No, this one is different. This one has seen us coming...

turns.speaker: CRAWFORD
turns.text: Talk about him, Starling. Tell me what you see.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: He's a white male... Serial killers tend to hunt within their own ethnic group. And he's not a drifter - he's got his own house, somewhere. Not an apartment.

turns.speaker: CRAWFORD
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: What he does with them - takes privacy... Time, tools... He's in his 30's or 40's - he's got real physical strength, but combined with an older man's self-control. He's cautious, precise, never impulsive... This won't end in suicide, like they often do.

turns.speaker: CRAWFORD
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: He's got a real taste for it now. And he's getting better at his work.

turns.speaker: CRAWFORD
turns.text: Maybe you've got a knack for this... I guess we're about to find out.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: Like I have a "knack" for Dr. Lecter?

turns.speaker: CRAWFORD
turns.text: Okay, Starling. Let's have it.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: You haven't said a word today about that garage. Or what I found there.

turns.speaker: CRAWFORD
turns.text: What should I say? You did fine work. We'll wait on the lab.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: You knew. You knew from the start that Lecter held the key to this... But you weren't up front with me. You sent me in to him naked.

turns.speaker: CRAWFORD
turns.text: Are you finished?

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: He starts this - buzzing in me, in my head. He makes me feel violated... You used me, Mr. Crawford.

turns.speaker: CRAWFORD
turns.text: What do you see, Starling?

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: Well, she's not local. Her ears are pierced three times each, and she's wearing green glitter nail polish. Looks like town to me...

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: I don't know. I didn't see those on any of the other girls...

turns.speaker: CRAWFORD
turns.text: They weren't there. Get close-ups.

turns.speaker: CRAWFORD
turns.text: When I told that sheriff we shouldn't talk in front of a woman, that really burned you, didn't it?  That was just smoke, Starling, I had to get rid of him. You did well in there.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: It matters, Mr. Crawford... Other cops know who you are. They look at you to see how to act... It matters.

turns.speaker: CRAWFORD
turns.text: Point taken.

turns.speaker: CRAWFORD
turns.text: When we get back, I want you to run that bug by the Smithsonian, see if they can identify it. Maybe it's got some limited range, or it only breeds at certain times of year... You found it, Starling, you deserve the credit.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: I'm wondering if he's done that before - placed a cocoon, or an insect. It would be easy to miss in an autopsy, especially with a floater... Can we check back on that?

turns.speaker: CRAWFORD
turns.text: The other girls are in the ground. Exhumations are upsetting for the families. I'll do it if I have to, but -

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: Then have the lab check Raspail's head.  Dr. Lecter's patient - have them probe his soft-palette tissues... They'll find another cocoon.

turns.speaker: CRAWFORD
turns.text: You seem pretty sure of that.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: Raspail was killed by the same man who's killing these girls. And Lecter knows him. Maybe even treated him... You think so, too, don't you? Or you'd never have sent me to that asylum.

turns.speaker: CRAWFORD
turns.text: But for Catherine Martin, it all comes down to you and Lecter. You're the one he talks to.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: He's already offered to help... What would happen if we just showed our cards - asked him for Bill?

turns.speaker: CRAWFORD
turns.text: He offered to help, Starling, not to snitch. That wouldn't give him enough chance to show off. Remember, Lecter looks mainly for fun. Never forget fun.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: But if he knew we have so little time -

turns.speaker: CRAWFORD
turns.text: If we act too anxious, he'll make us wait. He'll let the Senator keep hoping, day after day, until Catherine finally washes up. That'd be the most fun of all.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: I think he means it, this time. I think he'll deal.

turns.speaker: CRAWFORD
turns.text: What would it take?

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: Transfer to a new prison. With a view of trees, he said, or even water... Can we swing that?

turns.speaker: CRAWFORD
turns.text: State to federal jurisdiction... We can do it - eventually - but we'll never get all the clearances in time. Can you convince him a deal's already in place?

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: You'll back me up with some paperwork?  Then I'll try. But wouldn't this have more weight coming from the Senator herself?

turns.speaker: CRAWFORD
turns.text: She doesn't know what we're up to. And we can't afford to let her find out.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: Chilton has killed her, hasn't he? That slimy little bastard! We were so close with Lecter - and now her last chance is gone.

turns.speaker: CRAWFORD
turns.text: Let's get some coffee and talk.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: Are you in trouble over this, Mr. Crawford? Can Senator Martin do something to you?

turns.speaker: CRAWFORD
turns.text: I'm 53, Starling. If I found Jimmy Hoffa on national TV, I'd still have to retire in two years. It's not a consideration. But you are...  You've done enough. If I keep you out of school any longer, you'll be recycled. Cost you six months, at least. I can guarantee you readmission here, but that's about it.  Now's your chance, Starling. Go back to class. Leave Bill to me.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: If you didn't want me chasing him, you shouldn't have taken me to that funeral home.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: Lecter is still the key, I know he is. Whatever he told me about Bill is just as good now as it was before.

turns.speaker: CRAWFORD
turns.text: Or just as worthless. But I want you in Memphis, close to him. Maybe when he gets tired of toying with Senator Martin, he'll talk to you again. There's a plane waiting for you now at the airstrip.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: I lied to Lecter. I'll need some kind of peace offering... Can I get the drawings from his cell?

turns.speaker: CRAWFORD
turns.text: Good idea. Meantime, try to get a feel for Catherine Martin. Her apartment, her friends... how he might've stalked her. I'm going to the other two clinics, Minnesota and Ohio.  Now's the hardest part, Starling. Use your anger, don't let it keep you from thinking. Just keep your eyes on Catherine. We've got less than 30 hours.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: Mr. Crawford... can those cops down there handle Dr. Lecter?

turns.speaker: CRAWFORD
turns.text: They'll use their best men. But they better be paying attention...

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: All his victims are women... His obsession is women, he lives to hunt women. But not one women is hunting him - except me. I can walk in a woman's room and know three times as much about her as a man would.  I have to go to Belvedere.

turns.speaker: CRAWFORD
turns.text: You heard them. I don't have that authority anymore.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: You do until six p.m.

turns.speaker: CRAWFORD
turns.text: Ohio is cold ground. Picked over, ten months ago. Our people worked it, so did the locals.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: But not from this angle. Not thinking he knew her. You've got to send me!

turns.speaker: CRAWFORD
turns.text: I'm Bureau for 28 years, Starling. I won't disobey orders, not even now.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: But I just became a private citizen. I can go anywhere I want to.

turns.speaker: CRAWFORD
turns.text: With ID and a gun...? Impersonating a federal agent is a felony.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: He's going to kill her, Mr. Crawford. This morning, or maybe at noon, but today, and Belvedere's our last chance. I'm flying there, right now, unless you stop me. You want my ID? Here - take it...

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: He's making himself a "woman suit," Mr. Crawford - out of real women! And he can sew, this guy, he's really skilled. A dressmaker, or a tailor -

turns.speaker: CRAWFORD
turns.text: Starling -

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: That's why they're all so big - because he needs a lot of skin! He keeps them alive to starve them awhile - to loosen their skin, so that -

turns.speaker: CRAWFORD
turns.text: Starling, we know who he is! And where he is. We're on our way now.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: Where?

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: Sir, that's great news. But how -

turns.speaker: CRAWFORD
turns.text: Johns Hopkins finally came up with a name for us. We fed him into Known Offenders, and he came up cherries.  Subject's name is "Jamie Gumb," AKA "John Grant." Lecter's description was accurate, he just lied about the name.

turns.speaker: CRAWFORD
turns.text: This Gumb's a real beauty. Slaughtered both his grandparents when he was twelve, and did nine years in juvenile psychiatric. Where, Starling, he took vocational rehab, and learned a useful trade...

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: Sewing...

turns.speaker: CRAWFORD
turns.text: Take a bow. Customs had some paper on his alias. They stopped a carton two years ago at LAX - live caterpillars from Surinam. The addressee was "John Grant." Calumet Power & Light's given us two possible residences under that alias. We're hitting one, Chicago SWAT's taking the other.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: Chicago's only about 400 miles from here. I could be there in -

turns.speaker: CRAWFORD
turns.text: No, Starling, there isn't time. And you've still got crucial work to do in Ohio. We want him for murder, not kidnapping. I'm counting on you to link him to the Bimmel girl, before he's indicted.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: Yes sir... I'll do my best.

turns.speaker: CRAWFORD
turns.text: Starling - you've earned back your place in the Academy. We never would've found him without you, and nobody's ever going to forget that. Least of all me.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: Yes sir. Thank you, sir...

turns.speaker: PILCHER
turns.text: What do you do when you're not detecting, Officer Starling?

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: I try to be a student, Dr. Pilcher.

turns.speaker: PILCHER
turns.text: Ever get out for cheeseburgers and beer? The amusing house wine...?

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: Not lately. But maybe someday.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: And there's no way - no natural way - these could've wound up in the bodies?

turns.speaker: PILCHER
turns.text: They live in Malaysia. In this country, they'd have to be specially raised, from imported eggs.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: Dr. Lecter...

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: They said she was just rags, like somebody -

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: Stacy, did Fredrica ever mention a man named Jamie Gumb? Or John Grant?  Do you think she could've had a friend you didn't know about?

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: No way. She had a guy, I'da known, believe me. Sewing was her life, she was really great at it. Poor Freddie.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: Did you ever work with her?

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Oh sure, me'n Pam Malavesi used to help her do alterations for old Mrs. Lippman. Lots of people worked for her, she had the business from all these retail stores? But she was like, totally old, it was more'n she could handle.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: Where does Mrs. Lippman live? I'd like to talk to her.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: She died. She went to Florida to retire, like two years ago? She dies own there.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Is that a pretty good job, FBI agent?

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: I think so.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: You get to travel around and stuff? I mean, better places then this?

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: Sometimes you do.

turns.speaker: STACY
turns.text: Freddie was so happy for me when I got this job. This - toaster giveaways, and Barry Manilow on the speakers all day - she thought this was really hot shit. What did she know, big dummy...

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: Doctor, we have a hard problem in psychological profiling. I want to ask for your help with a questionnaire.

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: "We" being the Behavioral Science Unit, at Quantico. You're one of Jack Crawford's, I expect.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: I am, yes.

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: May I see your credentials?

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: That expires in one week. You're not real FBI, are you?

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: I'm - still in training at the Academy.

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: Jack Crawford sent a trainee to me?

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: We're talking about psychology, Doctor, not the Bureau. Can you decide for yourself whether or not I'm qualified?

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: Mmmmm... That's rather slippery of you, Officer Starling. Sit. Please.

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: Now then. What did Miggs say to you?  "Multiple Miggs," in the next cell. He hissed at you. What did he say?

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: He said - "I can smell your cunt."

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: I see. I myself cannot. You use Evyan skin cream, and sometimes you wear L'Air du Temps, but not today. You brought your best bag, though, didn't you?

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: It's much better than your shoes.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: Maybe they'll catch up.

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: I have no doubt of it.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: Did you do those drawings, Doctor?

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: Yes. That's the Duomo, seen from the Belvedere. Do you know Florence?

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: All that detail, just from memory...?

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: Memory, Officer Starling, is what I have instead of view.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: Dr. Lecter, if you'd please consider -

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: No, no, no. You were doing fine, you'd been courteous and receptive to courtesy, you'd established trust with the embarrassing truth about Miggs, and now this ham-handed segue into your questionnaire. It won't do. It's stupid and boring.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: I'm only asking you to look at this, Doctor. Either you will or you won't.

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: Jack Crawford must be very busy indeed if he's recruiting help from the student body. Busy hunting that new one, Buffalo Bill... Such a naughty boy! Did Crawford send you to ask for my advice on him?

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: No, I came because we need -

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: How many women has he used, our Bill?

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: Five... so far.

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: All flayed...?

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: Partially, yes. But Doctor, that's an active case, I'm not involved. If -

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: Do you know why he's called Buffalo Bill? Tell me. The newspapers won't say.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: I'll tell you if you'll look at this form.  It started as a bad joke in Kansas City Homicide. They said... this one likes to skin his humps.

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: Witless and misleading. Why do you think he takes their skins, Officer Starling? Thrill me with your wisdom.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: It excites him. Most serial killers keep some sort of trophies.

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: I didn't.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: No. You ate yours.

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: Oh, Officer Starling... do you think you can dissect me with this blunt little tool?

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: No. I only hoped that your knowledge -

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: You see a lot, Dr. Lecter. But are you strong enough to point that high- powered perception at yourself? How about it...? Look at yourself and write down the truth.  Or maybe you're afraid to.

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: You're a tough one, aren't you?

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: Reasonably so. Yes.

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: And you'd hate to think you were common. My, wouldn't that sting! Well you're far from common, Officer Starling. All you have is the fear of it.  Now please excuse me. Good day.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: And the questionnaire...?

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: A census taker once tried to test me. I ate his liver with some fava beans and a nice chianti... Fly back to school, little Starling.

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: I would not have had that happen to you. Discourtesy is - unspeakably ugly to me.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: Then please - do this test for me.

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: No. But I will make you happy... I'll give you a chance for what you love most, Clarice Starling.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: What's that, Dr. Lecter?

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: Advancement, of course.  Go to Split City. See Miss Mofet, an old patient of mine. M-O-F-E-T... Now go. Go.  I don't think Miggs could manage again so soon, even if he is crazy - do you?

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: Your bleeding has stopped.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: How did -  It's nothing. A scratch.

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: Why don't you ask me about Buffalo Bill?

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: Why? Do you know something about him?

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: I might if I saw the case file. You could get that for me.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: Why don't you tell me about "Miss Mofet?" You wanted me to find him. Or do I have to wait for the lab?

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: His real name is Benjamin Raspail. A former patient of mine, whose romantic attachments ran to, shall we say, the exotic...? I didn't kill him, merely tucked him away. Very much as I found him, in that ridiculous car, in his own garage, after he's missed three appointments. You'd have him under "Missing Person" - which, in poor Raspail's case, could hardly be more true.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: If you didn't kill him, then who did?

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: Who can say...? Best thing for him, really. His therapy was going nowhere.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: Wouldn't it have been easier to just leave him for the police to find?

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: And have them clomping about in my life? Oh dear, no... At that time I still had certain private amusements of my own.  How did you feel when you saw him, Clarice? May I call you Clarice?

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: Scared, at first. Then - exhilarated.

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: Ahhh... Why?

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: Because you weren't wasting my time.

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: Do you have something you use, when you need to get up your courage? Memories, tableaux... scenes from your early life?

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: I don't know. Next time I'll have to check.

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: Jack Crawford is helping your career, isn't he? Apparently he likes you. And you like him, too.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: I never thought about it.

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: Your first lie to me, Clarice. How sad. Tell me - do you think Crawford wants you, sexually? True, he's much older, but - do you think he visualizes... scenarios, exchanges...? Fucking you?

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: That doesn't interest me, Doctor. And it's the sort of thing Miggs would ask.

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: Not anymore.  Surely the odd confluence of events hasn't escaped you, Clarice. Crawford dangles you before me. Then I give you a bit of help. Do you think it's because I like to look at you, and imagine how good you would taste...?

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: I don't know. Is it?

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: Or doesn't this all begin to suggest to you a kind of... negotiation? There's something Crawford can give me, and I want to trade for it. I even wrote to him, offering my help. But he hates me, so he won't deal directly.

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: Punishment, you see. For Miggs. Just like that gospel program. When you leave, they'll turn the volume way up. Chilton does enjoy his petty torments.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: Who killed Raspail, Doctor...? You know, don't you?

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: I've been in this room for eight years, Clarice. I know they will never, ever let me out while I'm alive. What I want is a view. I want a window where I can see a tree, or even water. I want to be in a federal institution, away from Chilton - and I want a view. I'll give good value for it. Crawford could do that for me, but he won't. You persuade him.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: Who killed your patient?

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: Oh, a very naughty boy. Someone you and Jack Crawford are most anxious to meet.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: Buffalo Bill...?  Bill killed him, all those years ago...? That's impossible.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: I was your choice, Dr. Lecter. You chose to speak to me. Would you prefer someone else now? Or perhaps you don't think you can help us.

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: That is both impudent and untrue... Tell me, how did you feel when you viewed our Billy's latest effort?  Or should I say, his "next-to-latest"?

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: By the book, he's a sadist.

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: Life's too slippery for books, Clarice. Typhoid and swans came from the same God.  Tell me, Miss West Virginia - was she a large girl?

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: Big through the hips. Roomy.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: They all were.

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: Mmm. And what else...?

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: She had an insect deliberately inserted in her throat. That hasn't been made public yet. We don't know what is means.

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: Was it a butterfly?

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: A moth... How did you predict that?

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: I'm waiting for your offer, Clarice. Enchant me.

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: "Plum Island Animal Disease Research Center." Sounds charming.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: That's just part of the island. It has a very nice beach. Terns nest there.

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: Terns... If I help you, Clarice, it will be "turns" with us, too. Quid pro quo. I tell you things, you tell me things. Not about this case, though - about yourself. Yes or no?  Yes or no, Clarice. Catherine is waiting. Tick-tock, tick-tock...

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: Go, Doctor.

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: What's your worst memory of childhood?  Quicker than that. I'm not interested in your worst invention.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: The death of my father.

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: Tell me. Don't lie, or I'll know.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: He was a town marshal... one night he surprised two burglars, coming out the back of a drugstore... They shot him.

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: Killed outright?

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: No. He was strong, he lasted almost a month. My mother - died when I was very young, so my father had become - the whole world to me... After he left me, I had nobody. I was ten years old.

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: You're very frank, Clarice. I think - it would be quite something to know you in private life.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: Quid pro quo, Doctor.

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: The significance of the moth is change. Caterpillar into cocoon into beauty... Billy wants to change, too, Clarice. But there's the problem of his size, you see. Even if he were a woman, he'd have to be a big one...

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: Dr. Lecter, there's no correlation in the literature between transsexualism and violence. Transsexuals are very passive.

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: Clever girl. You're so close to the way you're going to catch him - do you realize that?

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: No. Tell me why.

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: After your father's death, you were orphaned. What happened next?  I don't imagine the answer's on those second-rate shoes, Clarice.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: I went to live with my mother's cousin and her husband in Montana. They had a ranch.

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: A cattle ranch?

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: Horses - and sheep...

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: How long did you live there?

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: Two months.

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: Why so briefly?

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: I - ran away...

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: Why, Clarice? Did the rancher fuck you?

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: Did he try to?

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: No...! Quid pro quo, Doctor.

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: Billy's not a real transsexual, but he thinks he is. He tries to be. He's tried to be a lot of things, I expect.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: You said - I was very close to the way we'd catch him.

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: There are three major centers for transsexual surgery: Johns Hopkins, the University of Minnesota, and Columbus Medical center. I wouldn't be surprised if Billy has applied for sex reassignment at one or all of them, and been rejected.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: On what basis would they reject him?

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: The personality inventories would trip him up. Rorschach, Wechsler, House-Tree-Person... He wouldn't test like a real transsexual.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: How would he test?

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: That's enough, I think. Happy hunting. Oh, and Clarice - next time you will tell me why you ran away. Shall I summarize?

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: Yes, Doctor. Please.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: I thought you might want your drawings back... Just until you get your view.

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: How very thoughtful... Or did Crawford send you here for one last wheedle - before you're both booted off the case?

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: Nobody sent me. I came on my own.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: Dr. Lecter, you find out everything. You couldn't have talked with this "William Rubin", even once, and come out knowing so little about him... You made him up, didn't you?

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: Clarice... you're hardly in a position to accuse me of lying.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: I think you were telling me the truth in Baltimore - or starting to. Tell me the rest now.

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: I've studied the case file, have you...? Everything you need to find him is right in these pages. Whatever his name is.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: Then tell me how.

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: First principles, Clarice. Simplicity. Read Marcus Aurelius. Of each particular thing, ask: What is it, in itself, what is its nature...? What does he do, this man you seek?

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: He kills w-

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: No! That's incidental.

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: What is the first and principal thing he does, what need does he serve by killing?

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: Anger, social resentment, sexual frus-

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: No, he covets. That's his nature. And how do we begin to covet, Clarice? Do we seek out things to covet? Make an effort to answer.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: No. We just -

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: No. Precisely. We begin by coveting what we see every day. Don't you feel eyes moving over your body, Clarice? I hardly see how you couldn't. And don't your eyes move over the things you want?

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: All right, then tell me how -

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: No. It's your turn to tell me, Clarice. You don't have any more vacations to sell, on Anthrax Island. Why did you run away from that ranch?

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: Dr. Lecter, when there's time I'll -

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: We don't reckon time the same way, Clarice. This is all the time you'll ever have.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: Later, listen, I'll -

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: I'll listen now. After your father's murder, you were orphaned. You were ten years old. You went to live with cousins, on a sheep and horse ranch in Montana. And - ?

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: And - one morning I just - ran away...

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: Not "just," Clarice. What set you off? You started what time?

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: Early. Still dark.

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: Then something woke you. What? Did you dream...? What was it?

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: I heard a strange sound...

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: What was it?

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: What did you do?

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: Got dressed without turning on the light. I went downstairs... outside...

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: They were slaughtering the spring lambs?

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: Yes...! They were screaming.

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: So you ran away...

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: No. First I tried to free them... I opened the gate of their pen - but they wouldn't run. They just stood there, confused. They wouldn't run...

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: But you could. You did.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: I took one lamb. And I ran away, as fast as I could...

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: Where were you going?

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: I don't know. I had no food or water. It was very cold. I thought - if I can even save just one... but he got so heavy. So heavy...

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: I didn't get more than a few miles before the sheriff's car found me. The rancher was so angry he sent me to live at the Lutheran orphanage in Bozeman. I never saw the ranch again...

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: But what became of your lamb?  Clarice...?

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: You still wake up sometimes, don't you? Wake up in the dark, with the lambs screaming?

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: Yes...

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: Do you think if you saved Catherine, you could make them stop...? Do you think, if Catherine lives, you won't wake up in the dark, ever again, to the screaming of the lambs? Do you...?

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: Yes! I don't know...! I don't know.

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: Thank you, Clarice.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: Tell me his name, Dr. Lecter.

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: Dr. Chilton... I believe you know each other?

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: Brave Clarice. Will you let me know if ever the lambs stop screaming?

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: Yes. I'll tell you.

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: Promise...?  Then why not take your case file? I won't be needing it anymore.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: Starling.

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: Well, Clarice, have the lambs stopped screaming...?

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: Your lambs are still for now, Clarice, but not forever... You'll have to earn it again and again, this blessed silence. Because it's the plight that drives you, and the plight will never end.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: Dr. Lecter -

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: I have no plans to call on you, Clarice, the world being more interesting with you in it. Be sure you extend me the same courtesy.

turns.speaker: CLARICE
turns.text: You know I can't make that promise.

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: Goodbye, Clarice...  You looked - so very lovely today, in your blue suit.

turns.speaker: DR. DANIELSON
turns.text: I'm not having a witch hunt here, Mr. Crawford! Our patients are decent, non-violent people with a real problem.

turns.speaker: CRAWFORD
turns.text: Dr. Danielson, the man we want was never your patient. It would be someone you refused because he tries to conceal a record of criminal violence. Please, Doctor - time is eating us up. Just show me the ones you've turned away.

turns.speaker: DR. DANIELSON
turns.text: Examination and interview materials are confidential. We've never violated an applicant's trust, and we never will.

turns.speaker: CRAWFORD
turns.text: You want to see a violation? This is a violation...

turns.speaker: CRAWFORD
turns.text: Her name is Kimberly Jane Emberg, she was just ID'd. I met her on a slab in West Virginia. And sometime tomorrow, or tomorrow night, he's going to do the same thing to Catherine Martin.

turns.speaker: DR. DANIELSON
turns.text: That's a childish, bullying stunt, Mr. Crawford. I was a battlefield surgeon, so you can put away your picture.

turns.speaker: CRAWFORD
turns.text: Look... search your own records, if you prefer. You can do it a lot faster than us, anyway. If we find Buffalo Bill through your information, I'll suppress it. Nobody has to know this hospital cooperated.

turns.speaker: DR. DANIELSON
turns.text: I doubt very much that the FBI or any other government agency can keep a secret, Mr. Crawford. Truth will out... And then what? Will you give Johns Hopkins a new identity? Put a big pair of sunglasses on this building, and a funny nose?

turns.speaker: CRAWFORD
turns.text: Oh, that's clever, Dr. Danielson. Very humorous. You like the truth? Try this.  He kidnaps young women and kills them and rips their skin off. We don't want him to do that anymore. If you don't help me, just as fast as you can, then the Justice Department is going to ask publicly for a court order, We'll ask twice a day, just in time for the morning and evening news. And each one of our press conferences will focus on Dr. Danielson, over at Johns Hopkins, and how we're still hoping for his cooperation. And every time there's any news on the case - when Catherine Martin floats, when the next one floats, and the next one - why, we'll just issue another press release about good ol' Dr. Danielson, over at Johns Hopkins - complete with all his humorous fucking remarks.

turns.speaker: DR. DANIELSON
turns.text: It may be that - I could confer with my colleagues on this. And get back to you.

turns.speaker: CRAWFORD
turns.text: Would you, Doctor? That would be so kind.

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: I won't waste your time and Catherine's time bargaining for petty privileges. Clarice Starling and that awful Jack Crawford have wasted far too much already. I only pray they haven't doomed the poor girl... Let me help you now, and I'll trust you when it's all over.

turns.speaker: SEN. MARTIN
turns.text: You have my word. Paul?

turns.speaker: SEN. MARTIN
turns.text: What...?

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: Did you breast-feed her?

turns.speaker: SEN. MARTIN
turns.text: Yes... I did.

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: Toughened your nipples, didn't it...?  Six foot one, strongly built, about 190 pounds. Hair brown, eyes pale blue. He'd be about 35 now. He said he lived in Philadelphia, but may have lied. That's really all I can remember, Senator - but if I think of any more, I'll let you know.

turns.speaker: SEN. MARTIN
turns.text: Let's go with it.

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: Senator Martin...! You can't trust Jack Crawford or Clarice Starling. It's such a game with these people. They're determined to get the arrest for themselves. The "collar," I think they say.

turns.speaker: SEN. MARTIN
turns.text: Thank you, Doctor. I'll keep it in mind.

turns.speaker: DR. LECTER
turns.text: Oh, and Senator...? Love you suit.

turns.speaker: RODEN
turns.text: Time, Pilch! My move.

turns.speaker: PILCHER
turns.text: No fair! You lured him with produce.

turns.speaker: RODEN
turns.text: Of course it counts. How do you play?

turns.speaker: PILCHER
turns.text: Officer Starling. Welcome back.

turns.speaker: PILCHER
turns.text: Your West Virginia specimen gave us quite a bit of trouble, but I finally managed to narrow his species through chaetaxy - studying the skin.

turns.speaker: RODEN
turns.text: I'm the one who found his perforating proboscis! Are you wearing a gun, right now?  Ooh, cool! Can I see it? Can I?

turns.speaker: PILCHER
turns.text: Just ignore him. He's not a Ph.D.

turns.speaker: RODEN
turns.text: Better known to his friends as the Death's-head Moth...

turns.speaker: PILCHER
turns.text: The Latin name comes from two rivers in Hell. Your man - he drops these girls into rivers, every time. Didn't I read that?

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: My God, you've grown up.

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: We leave in the morning?!

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: Yes, miss.

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: I won't sleep tonight. What an adventure!  I absolutely cannot wait to return to Portman Square, having laid eyes upon the full-blooded, red men in the wild!

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: Are you alright?

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: Can we rest soon?

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: Absolutely.

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: The men of the regiment will fetch water from the lake, build fires and provide every comfort you desire, Alice...

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: Duncan, you are absolutely gallant. If Cora doesn't marry you, I shall.

turns.speaker: CORA
turns.text: Though they are strangers, they are at least entitled to a Christian burial!

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: Let us go, miss.

turns.speaker: CORA
turns.text: I will not. I have seen the face of war before, Mr. Poe, but never war made on women and children. And almost as cruel is your indifference.

turns.speaker: CORA
turns.text: Why didn't you bury those people?

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: Anyone lookin' to pick up our trail, would see it as a sign of our passing...

turns.speaker: CORA
turns.text: You knew them.

turns.speaker: CORA
turns.text: You were acting for our benefit. And I apologize. I misunderstood you.

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: Well that is to be expected. My father...

turns.speaker: CORA
turns.text: Your "father"?

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: Chingachgook. He warned me about people like you.

turns.speaker: CORA
turns.text: He did?

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: Yes. He said... "do not try to make them understand you."

turns.speaker: CORA
turns.text: What?!

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: Yes. And "do not try to understand them.  That is because they are a breed apart and they make no sense..."

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: The Ottawa are gone.

turns.speaker: CORA
turns.text: Why did they turn back?

turns.speaker: CORA
turns.text: "We're a breed apart and we make no sense"...?

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: In your particular case, miss, I would make some allowance...

turns.speaker: CORA
turns.text: Thank you so much.

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: They buried my ma & pa and my sisters. And Chingachgook - who found me with two French trappers - raised me up as his own.

turns.speaker: CORA
turns.text: I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: I do not remember them. I was one or two.

turns.speaker: CORA
turns.text: How did you learn English?

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: My father sent Uncas & I to Reverend Wheelock's school when I was ten. So we would know both worlds... though we were told only bother learning readin' & arithmetic from yours.

turns.speaker: CORA
turns.text: And what were the consequentialities of European culture you didn't bother with?

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: The Bible. Monarchy. Many wrong ideas about the government of men. My father's people already know each man is his own nation. And only he can have dominion over himself. Not kings. No man is better than any other man.

turns.speaker: CORA
turns.text: In London those radical ideas could land you in Newgate prison.  Why were those people living in this defenseless place...?

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: 'Cos frontier land's the only land affordable to poor people. So after seven years indentured service in Virginia, they headed out here where they are beholden to none and not livin' by another's leave...  Their name was Cameron. John & Alexandria.

turns.speaker: CORA
turns.text: You are right, Mr. Poe. We do not understand what is happening here. And it is not as I imagined it would be, thinking of it in Boston and London...

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: Sorry to disappoint you...

turns.speaker: CORA
turns.text: On the contrary. It is more deeply stirring...  to my blood...  ...than any imagining could possibly have been...

turns.speaker: CORA
turns.text: Much further?

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: Top of this ridge. Fort and Lake George are downhill of it.

turns.speaker: CORA
turns.text: Mr Poe?

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: Miss.  May I?

turns.speaker: CORA
turns.text: What are you looking at, Mr. Poe?

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: Why, I am looking at you, Miss.

turns.speaker: CORA
turns.text: They're going to hang you.  Why didn't you leave when you had the chance?

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: Because what I am interested in is right here...

turns.speaker: CORA
turns.text: What would you have me do?

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: Webb's reinforcements will arrive or not.  If they do not arrive, the fort will fall. If that happens, stay close to your father.  The French will protect the officer class among the English.

turns.speaker: CORA
turns.text: No. I will find you.

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: Do not.  Promise me.

turns.speaker: CORA
turns.text: What is it?

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: I don't know. Whatever happens you stay with your father. You stay among the officers.

turns.speaker: CORA
turns.text: Are we safe?

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: Maybe...

turns.speaker: CORA
turns.text: Our father? Did you see my father?

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: In this there is a chance. If I live, I can try to free you. If we don't go, there is no powder, there's too many of them.  Though my heart would keep me here, in that there is no chance. None. I can do nothing. Do you understand?

turns.speaker: CORA
turns.text: Yes. I want you to go.

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: Listen. Submit. You hear me?  You're strong. You stay alive. I will find you...  no matter how far, how long it takes...

turns.speaker: CORA
turns.text: ...never doubt what you are doing.

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: And my compliments to you...

turns.speaker: CORA
turns.text: Alice?

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: Will you go back to England?

turns.speaker: CORA
turns.text: I have nothing to go back for.

turns.speaker: CORA
turns.text: Where will we go?

turns.speaker: HAWKEYE
turns.text: Winter with the Delaware, my father's cousins. And in the spring, cross the Ohio and look for land to settle with my father in a new place called Can-tuck-ee.

turns.speaker: MUNRO
turns.text: Told you to stay away from this hell hole!  Why did you disobey me?

turns.speaker: CORA
turns.text: When? How?

turns.speaker: MUNRO
turns.text: My letter...

turns.speaker: CORA
turns.text: There was none!

turns.speaker: MUNRO
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: CORA
turns.text: There was no letter.

turns.speaker: MUNRO
turns.text: I sent three men to Webb!

turns.speaker: MUNRO
turns.text: The man encouraged the colonials to desert in this very room, in my presence. He is guilty of sedition and must be tried and hanged like any other criminal, regardless of what he did for my children.

turns.speaker: CORA
turns.text: He knew the consequences. And he stayed.  Are those the actions of a criminal?  ...Duncan, do something.

turns.speaker: MUNRO
turns.text: But the man is guilty of sedition and subject to military justice and beyond pardon.

turns.speaker: CORA
turns.text: "Justice"?  If that's "justice"..., then the sooner French guns blow the English army out of America, the better it will be for these people.

turns.speaker: MUNRO
turns.text: You do not know what you are saying!

turns.speaker: CORA
turns.text: Yes I do! I know exactly what I am saying.  And if it is sedition, then I am guilty of sedition, too!

turns.speaker: CORA
turns.text: I'm embarrassed to be so indecisive... after so long apart and after you've traveled so far...

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: And by sea!

turns.speaker: CORA
turns.text: You still have an aversion to the water?

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: Aversion?  No... "Hatred"... "Loathing"...

turns.speaker: CORA
turns.text: Dear Duncan, my affection is as towards a closest friend. Alice and I depend on you and respect you immensely... I wish they did, but my feelings don't go beyond that. Do you see?

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: Isn't respect and friendship, a reasonable basis for a man and woman to be joined? And all else may grow in time...?

turns.speaker: CORA
turns.text: Some say that's the way of it.

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: "Some"?

turns.speaker: CORA
turns.text: Cousin Eugenie, my father, but...

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: Cora, in my heart, I know once we're joined, we'll be the happiest couple in England. Let those whom you trust, your father, help settle what's best for you. In view of your indecision, why not rely on their advice and judgment as well as mine?

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: Will you consider that?

turns.speaker: CORA
turns.text: Yes. Yes, I will.

turns.speaker: CORA
turns.text: My God, Alice.

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: It can be dangerous...

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: One called Magua arrived.

turns.speaker: CORA
turns.text: He delivered no such message.

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: Cora, I adore you and, when we come together, we will be the happiest couple in England...  I am certain of that. More than ever before.  I believe you must trust the judgment of others who hold your welfare so close to their hearts...

turns.speaker: CORA
turns.text: Duncan...  Duncan, I promised you an answer. You have complimented me with your persistence and patience... But the decision I've come to is I'd rather make the gravest of mistakes than surrender my own judgment.

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: I see...

turns.speaker: CORA
turns.text: I am sorry, Duncan...

turns.speaker: CORA
turns.text: beyond the periphery of men, staring at him.

turns.speaker: HEYWARD
turns.text: Munro is expecting him to be the good soldier in defense of British military interests.
